description: Explore the culture, values & lifestyle of the Indigenous people of the Humber Valley. Fully experiential, participate in a traditional ceremony, learn how to create their music, hear the wisdom of their teachings and sample some local food. Part of your fee funds a skills-development program for women from the Indigenous community living in Toronto.

reviews.title: Felt like we were in Algonquin
text: Our group of 10 adults, 1 teenager, and 4 kids loved the hike and enjoyed the multi-sensory experience, it was both enjoyable and enlightening.
The guide was knowledgeable and able to speak to all ages.
Thank you for a great outing.

reviews.title: Virtual Earth Day Lesson on Biomimicry
text: I have two favvourite parts. First, I appreciated the way Lisa created a very interesting online lesson about biomimicry. Second, I liked the fact that she used a neighbourhood example to give our students a collaborative challenge.

reviews.title: Wonderful experience
text: Lisa was amazingly knowledgeable and really inspired us to think outside the box and take a closer look at things in nature. My kids loved it and we will do another tour for sure.

reviews.title: Fantastic nature experience!
text: Lisa led an enjoyable nature walk through the trails of southern Ontario. Not only were there spectacular views along the walk but she also educates and provides you with activities to enhance your connection with nature and those around you. The hike was a relaxing and adventurous experience. Lisa teaches that through the connection with nature we can be our happiest and most authentic selves which is a key component to achieving our life dreams. Highly recommend!

reviews.title: Team build during Covid
text: Lise did an amazing job leading my team from work on a guided tour focusing on nature and mindfulness. She was well prepared for social distancing and sanitizing. We spent two hours walking through the York regional forest. It’s the first time the group of us have been together since the first week of March in person. She dId a great job helping us all reconnect again. Thanks Lisa!

reviews.title: Nature can be our teacher, if we pay attention....
text: Lisa Gervais articulately offers a range of experiences and information in different natural settings which show how insects, plants, birds and other fellow Earthlings have much to teach us humans about effective and responsive design. The natural settings of Toronto's Don Valley and the Brickworks are inspiring locations for Lisa's invitations to consider relationships within the natural world as examples of innovation in response to challenges we face. A worthwhile and important experience.

reviews.title: What we can learn from nature is a lot!
text: Lisa Gervais is a spirited and incredibly knowledgeable guide through Toronto's treasured ravines. She opens our eyes to what is right around us and human innovations inspired by nature. The walk was a delight and is suitable to all ages.

reviews.title: Great day on the Humber
text: The walk is an enjoyable and needed get away from Canada’s busiest city. The calming effect of nature along the Humber includes engaging discussion of positive Psychology as well as indigenous history and traditions that emphasize their oneness with nature.

reviews.title: A Walk in Toronto about Learning from Nature
text: Lisa led an enjoyable and informative 2.5-hour Sunday afternoon walk through a beautiful and wooded part of Toronto - the woods near the Evergreen Brick Works. She emphasized various ways in which people can better learn to create and innovate by looking to how nature works. I'm glad that I took part in the walk.

reviews.title: A Smart and Spirited tour of the Humber river
text: What a find!  The best tour and tour guide took me through a hidden and rejuvenated gem of a watershed.  She deftly combined history, ecology, art and local indigenous wisdom in an compelling format.  Don’t miss this opportunity to spend time with Lisa. Turns out she too is quite a gem!

reviews.title: Fantastic Tour -- Walk In The Footsteps Of Toronto's First Nations People
text: Just back from one of the best tours I have ever experienced in my life. Thanks to Redwing Institute, I now see Toronto from a whole new perspective. Not only did we see beautiful scenery that I would never see on any other tour of Toronto, but I came away learning more about indigenous people, nature, and history. I also learned more about myself and gained some new ways to get more out of my life. The best part is that the blend of gentle exercise and the experiential nature of the three hour programme made it fun, while introducing me to new information on several fronts, I feel inspired, happy and ready to learn more.
If you are coming to Toronto I would make taking this tour your number one priority.
Thank you Lisa, for your excellent facilitation skills and for your hard work in creating such an outstanding programme. I also loved the bannock bread and maple syrup!

Having worked with youth for more than 3 decades, I hope that school students will have the chance to go on this tour. I think it is a learning experience that will benefit them for the rest of their lives!

reviews.title: Lovely morning out in the city
text: My husband and I took this tour this morning.  We have biked this area often and have canoed up the Humber River many times.   We were pleasantly surprised to learn a few more things about the area - especially all the indigenous culture information Lisa told us about.   It was about 4.5 km of walking but it was over three hours.   We made music, drank cedar tea, ate bannock and maple syrup.   A great learning experience.  I would recommend this to everyone - those that live here and haven't explored the area well, and to all visitors to our city to learn about our First Nations.

reviews.title: A must-do experience!!!
text: I  have lived in Toronto most of my life and Lisa introduced me to a new area that I had never experienced. Practicing law and teaching at the college level in Toronto, I believe that the Redwing Institute Walking Tour is a great opportunity for team building, expanding young minds with respect to the impact of the Indigenous people on Toronto or having a different (and very fun) experience with friends. The music portion of the walk is particularly engaging. The freshly baked Bannock bread and Ontario maple syrup are absolutely delic. Wear comfortable shoes, bring water and a camera and be ready for a Toronto experience like no other.

reviews.title: A great insight into Toronto's indigenous beginnings
text: My fiancee and I attended a walk this past week and had a wonderful time. Lisa, our guide, was informative and enthusiastic. As someone who has lived in Toronto for years but knows little of the area's native roots, it was an excellent opportunity to learn and see some of the beautiful parks and trails practically within the city.

reviews.title: Incredible and very interactive Tour.
text: I experienced Toronto's indigenous people ceremonies and their seven principles. I really liked the part when we made music like the First Nations' people . Make sure you bring water and sunscreen. It's just a lovely area to walk through.

reviews.title: Awesome Tour! Don't miss this attraction.
text: My daughter and I had a wonderful afternoon with Lisa!  She opened our eyes to the beauty and history of the Humber River and we especially loved the sensory part of the tour -- smells, sounds, sights and taste --- mmmm loved that bread!!  Learning more about our heritage through the history and experiences of the indigenous people who lived here centuries before us was fascinating. Bravo!

reviews.title: Excellent
text: This tour is a great option to get to learn different things about the Humber River area early history, a very unique thing to do. Lisa is an awesome tour guide, knowledgeable and a great person to talk to, she will certainly keep you entertained!

reviews.title: Nice walk along the Humber River
text: It was a beautiful day for this nature and educational walk. Learned about the indigenous influence on the Humber River area that I didn't know of before. Lisa was very friendly and knowledgeable. Her bannock bread was delicious!

reviews.title: Great nature walk in the middle of Toronto
text: This is a great way to explore the more nature-oriented side of Toronto. Lisa is an awesome guide and very informative on indigenous culture. A must-do!

reviews.title: A great way to learn more on my city Toronto
text: I enjoyed this educational walk and I highly recommend anyone who wants to find out more about the history of Toronto and about native indians culture. It also is a great place to explore and a great hike.

reviews.title: Truly enjoyed this discovery walk
text: I had the pleasure to experience this informative walking tour along the beautiful Humber River.

Lisa our tour guide was well informed on the history of the First Nation people that once resided in that part of Toronto. Through her well narrated tour we experienced a ceremonial smudging, she had us participating in a chanting and drum session and we even got to sample cedar tea and bannock.
I recommend this unique nature walk.

reviews.title: Unique experience
text: Pleasant and informative excursion. I have walked in that area many times when I lived nearby and had no idea about the history of it all. It was a unique and fun experience!

reviews.title: Much More Than a Walk in the Park
text: I found out about Redwing Institute and the walking tours through a flyer and I am so glad I did! It was informative, experiential and enlivening as we moved through each location. Wonderful surprises on the water and in the trees with an incredibly generous guide who made sure to spend time with each member of the group offering that personal attention.
A must-do at any time of year!

reviews.title: Wonderful and informative walking tour in a truly beautiful part of the city.
text: My daughter and I experienced a unique and informative walking tour in early autumn in a part of Toronto that we had yet to discover.

Our tour was led by Lisa, also the owner, who unfolded the history of the First Nations people that once resided along the banks of the Humber River. Throughout the tour, we were provided with samples of bannock and cedar tea, participated in a smudging ceremony and were introduced to the ceremonial drum. Under a clear blue sky, we enjoyed a great history lesson while walking in a truly beautiful setting along with a fun group of people and with our engaging and knowledgeable tour guide.

For newcomers to the city, visitors, and Torontonians that have yet to explore this part of the city, I highly recommend this great opportunity to spend some worthwhile time outdoors. And don’t forget to bring your camera.

reviews.title: New Perspective on Cultural and Natural History
text: I'm relatively new to Toronto, and Lisa from Redwing Institute introduced me to an area of the city I'd never ventured into. The tour explains how the Humber Valley was used through the centuries by First Nations and demonstrates how traditional teachings can be applied on a daily basis as we consider nature and our place within it. It was fantastic to connect with the other guests on the tour - conversations flowed as easily as the river !

reviews.title: Culture & Nature Discovery Walk
text: An enlightening, nourishing exploration of an almost unknown part of Toronto. Redwing Institute allowed us to learn and observe and experience nature and the local native history.Everyone should do this walking tour with Redwing!

reviews.title: Raised our consciousness and appreciation of Toronto's native history
text: Lisa (owner and tourguide) gave us a memorable and thought provoking experience. The 4 hour nature walking tour focusing on the Humber river and its First Nations history. Our hands on interactions with first nations music, food, drink, and medicines were the highlights. The trails were gentle, but beautifully wooded and full of unique plant and animal sightings that helped us take a glimpse into the abundant natural resources and biodiversity of the city.

In addition to the tour itself, what is truly memorable is Lisa's social consciousness and dedication to charities, groups and causes promoting empowerment of the First Nations People. A truly genuine walk, led by someone who truly cares about preserving the future of a vastly important culture.
Also - great news that there will be upcoming Spanish language tours as well to broaden the cultural reach of the institute's message.

reviews.title: Great blend of nature walk and history
text: On a beautiful sunny day we went to excellent nooks and crannies on the Humber River and learned in an interactive way about its history and especially how indigenous peoples utilized and viewed the area in the past and today. Information was provided in many ways: pictorially, factually, and handling of artifacts.Our guide went to alot of trouble to have us taste indigenous foods, learn first hand about ceremonial practices and to  experience indigenous drumming and singing. Easy subway access to the starting point and a lovely walking trail to Lake Ontario.

reviews.title: Seeing another Toronto
text: Facilitated superbly by Lisa, this tour provided an informative and inspiring view of the Humber from a First Nation's perspective. Highlights included eating bannock and drinking cedar tea, playing traditional instruments, and learning about the culture and natural environment of this area of Toronto in an unhurried and mindful way. A great way to spend three hours!

reviews.title: Best day of my summer
text: This extremely informative and enjoyable tour is a perfect way for both residents and visitors to experience the city in a new way but also for any teacher who wants to give their students a chance to spend time in nature while learning about everything from ecology, urban planning and story telling to music, history and aboriginal culture in an experiential way. Lisa was able to impart her knowledge of and respect for Aboriginal history and culture in an engaging and interactive way that left participants with a greater appreciation for the contributions and enduring presence of Aboriginal Peoples on this land. Not only were we kept physically, mentally and spiritually nourished (love the Bannock!) during the tour but Lisa also offers followup so that participants can stay connected, learn ways to get involved in the community and continue their learning journey. Cant wait to bring my class and all of my out-of-town guests!

reviews.title: Informative and enjoyable!
text: This was a very informative and insightful journey that our CBRE committee took to learn more about First Nations history. I was impressed with the diligence and scope of materials provided (smudge ceremony, music, traditions, tea and bannock). It was a rainy/cool day but Lisa's spirit, enthusiasm kept us engaged.

reviews.title: Beautiful and informative!
text: I was looking for something fun to do with my adult niece here from Australia and Lisa's tour more than fit the bill. We both loved the guided walk along the Humber and I saw a part of Toronto that I had never seen, even though I've lived here my whole life. Lisa was very knowledgeable about the indigenous history in the area and made her stories come to life with food and drink samples as well as by having us play traditional music. More surprises kept coming out of her bottomless backpack!
Thanks, Lisa, for a great day.

reviews.title: A total pleasure
text: If you want a personalized tour with an exceptional guide of the Toronto nature scene, this is the tour for you! Lisa is first class as a tour guide.

reviews.title: Walking Tour of The Humber
text: Thank you so much Lisa, I had such a great time, your a wonderful tour guide. Bravo for creating such engaging, interactive, fun and informative experience in nature and real Toronto and native Canadian history. I live in a Tobico and I had no idea that so much rich culture was right under my nose in my own backyard! Highly recommend the experience to everyone!

reviews.title: What a Fun Way to Spend an Afternoon!
text: The tour was absolutely spectacular. Lisa is a superstar. I work for a tour guide company and we did this as a staff event and every single one of us had a great time. Lisa's tour is so engaging and interactive. What a refreshing experience. So hands-on and fun. Lisa is a superstar.

reviews.title: Meaningful Toronto Experience
text: This tour is for those who want to step away from the hustle and bustle to experience the origins of Toronto -- learning about the culture, stories, and wisdom of the First People who named this region. I was so impressed with Lisa's knowledge and thoughtfulness as a tour guide. Each part of the walking tour is marked with a sensory experience. This truly meaningful journey deepened my appreciation for the Indigenous People and Toronto's natural beauty. Highly recommend!

reviews.title: sisters weekend
text: My sister and I just had a wonderful day with Lisa our guide .
I discover the  rich history on our nature walk of our indigenous people along the Humber river.
Lisa was sweet and a fun person,
She had a lot of  stories and facts about the Humber Valley.
She made the 3 and half hours amazing. We have beauty(historical and nature) in Toronto that everyone needs to explore.

reviews.title: My great gift for mother's day!
text: Lisa pampered us nicely throughout the tour, I just relaxed and enjoyed! My family had a great time, my children did not realized the distance they walked due to the fun activities Lisa coordinated throughout the tour

reviews.title: A wonderful and enriching experience for our Fourth Grade students!
text: This was more than your average nature walk. Lisa provided multiple rich experiential learning activities and lead discussions on the connections between the history of the land and the cultures and indigenous peoples that have called the Humber Valley home over the centuries.  Our students had a ton of fun and came away with a greater appreciation of the cultural heritage and natural beauty of a gorgeous area right in Toronto!

reviews.title: On site custom program
text: "I booked an on-site custom program with Redwing Institute for the retirement residence where I work and I was totally blown away by the presentation Lisa brought to our retirement residence. Interactive, educational and loads of fun. From beginning to end the residents were fully engulfed in the history of the Humber River valley. The use of native customs brought the residents alive. I would highly recommend The on-site presentation to any retirement residence looking for something unique. Lisa related so well with her audience expressing her vast knowledge of culture and relating that knowledge in a way that kept the residents attentive to the subject matter.
